cluster_classes.class_description: Legacy aggregate class that previously bundled general adult butterflies and female butterflies; concepts have been split into dedicated classes and this class is retained only for backward compatibility.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: adult butterflies, including female butterflies that lay eggs on host plants
remarks: This class is now empty after splitting its members into more precise classes. Prefer using 'Adult butterflies (all sexes)' or 'Female butterflies' going forward.

This class is an empty legacy aggregate for adult butterflies and should be treated as deprecated; avoid adding new members and prefer the dedicated 'Adult butterflies' and 'Female butterflies' classes.
This class is intentionally kept empty as a deprecated legacy aggregate; schema consumers should migrate to 'Adult butterflies' and 'Female butterflies' and avoid using this class going forward.

cluster_classes.class_description: Adult butterflies as whole organisms, representing the adult life stage and endpoint of metamorphosis, regardless of sex.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: adult butterflies, including female butterflies that lay eggs on host plants

members.entity_description: A butterfly, an insect of the order Lepidoptera that undergoes complete metamorphosis through egg, larva (caterpillar), pupa (chrysalis), and adult stages.
Adult form that the caterpillar develops into after completing metamorphosis.

args.new_description: DEPRECATED legacy aggregate class that previously bundled general adult butterflies and female butterflies. All former members have been moved into more precise classes (e.g., 'Adult butterflies' and 'Female butterflies'). This class is retained only for backward compatibility and must not receive new members.
args.remark: This class is intentionally kept empty as a deprecated legacy aggregate; schema consumers should migrate to 'Adult butterflies' and 'Female butterflies' and avoid using this class going forward.
args.justification: The class is an empty, deprecated legacy aggregate for adult butterflies; renaming and updating its type hint and description makes its deprecated status explicit and prevents future misuse while preserving it for backward compatibility.

executed_decisions.new_description: DEPRECATED legacy aggregate class that previously bundled general adult butterflies and female butterflies. All former members have been moved into more precise classes (e.g., 'Adult butterflies' and 'Female butterflies'). This class is retained only for backward compatibility and must not receive new members.
executed_decisions.remark: This class is intentionally kept empty as a deprecated legacy aggregate; schema consumers should migrate to 'Adult butterflies' and 'Female butterflies' and avoid using this class going forward.
executed_decisions.justification: The class is an empty, deprecated legacy aggregate for adult butterflies; renaming and updating its type hint and description makes its deprecated status explicit and prevents future misuse while preserving it for backward compatibility.

cluster_classes.class_description: Abstract ideas referring to phenomena beyond normal scientific understanding, including the supernatural, the paranormal, and the broader notion of the unknown and its existence in people's beliefs and imaginations.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Phenomena or entities believed to exist beyond normal scientific understanding; unexplained or mysterious aspects of reality.

members.entity_description: Phenomena or entities believed to exist beyond normal scientific understanding, frequently referenced in explanatory stories and urban legends.
Broad concept of unexplained or mysterious aspects of reality that provoke curiosity and fear, often addressed in stories and folklore.
Events or phenomena that appear beyond normal experience or scientific explanation, associated with legends and hauntings.
The question of whether supernatural phenomena are real in listeners’ lives.

cluster_classes.class_description: Story-focused entities and narrative frames centered on supernatural or unexplained events in folklore and urban legends, including tales about the supernatural and unresolved mysteries that drive such stories.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Stories focusing on supernatural phenomena and unexplained events; unresolved questions that inspire continued creation of legends.

members.entity_name: tales of the supernatural and the unknown
members.entity_description: Stories focusing on supernatural phenomena and unexplained or mysterious events.
Unresolved questions or unexplained events that inspire continued creation of urban legends.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concrete locations, objects, beings, and manifestations associated with supernatural activity, such as haunted houses, cursed objects, ghostly apparitions, and mysterious creatures in legends.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Haunted houses, ghostly apparitions, and mysterious creatures as central figures in supernatural legends.

members.entity_description: Houses or locations believed to be inhabited or influenced by ghosts or supernatural entities, frequently depicted as dangerous settings in urban legends and folklore.
Unusual, unidentified, or supernatural beings that appear as central figures in many legends and urban myths, often evoking fear and curiosity.
Visual manifestations of ghosts or spirits, commonly described in supernatural stories and legends.
Objects believed to carry a curse, bringing misfortune or danger to those who encounter them.

cluster_classes.class_description: Narrative stories that depict threats and negative consequences to warn audiences about risks in the world, especially through urban legend motifs.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: cautionary tales and dangers that lurk in the world around them

members.entity_description: Stories intended to warn audiences about risks, dangers, or undesirable behaviors, often by depicting negative consequences.
Various threats, harms, or risks portrayed as lurking in the world in cautionary urban legends.

cluster_classes.class_label: Predatory Strangers in Cautionary Urban Legends
cluster_classes.class_description: Unfamiliar adults depicted as potential predators who attempt to lure or harm children in cautionary urban legend narratives.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: unfamiliar adults depicted as potential predators who attempt to lure children

members.entity_description: Unfamiliar adults depicted as potential predators who attempt to lure children in urban legend stories.

cluster_classes.class_description: Intangible backstories and conditions that imbue supernatural settings and elements with danger, such as dark or violent pasts and histories that make places or items feel cursed in urban legends.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: haunted houses with dark pasts, and cursed objects

members.entity_description: Troubling or violent histories associated with haunted houses in these urban legend descriptions.

remarks: After moving cursed objects to the phenomena/manifestations class, this class is focused on narrative backstory/condition rather than concrete items; label and description updated accordingly.
Standardizing the class_group label to match the other supernatural-related classes; previous value contained a typo ('Parannormal').

cluster_classes.class_description: Abstract socio-technical processes that enable the spread and rapid transmission of information, including improvements in technology and communication methods.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Advancements in technology and communication platforms enable rapid transmission of information and proliferation of urban legends.

members.entity_description: Improvements in technological capabilities and tools that enable faster and broader dissemination of information, including urban legends.
Means of transmitting information, identified as enabling faster spread of urban legends.
The fast spread and sharing of information enabled by modern communication channels.

cluster_classes.class_description: Digital and networked channels such as the internet and social media platforms that enable rapid, wide dissemination of stories and other content to large audiences.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: In the age of the internet and social media, stories can be shared and disseminated at lightning speed.

members.entity_description: Global digital network described as a medium that accelerates sharing of stories and legends.
Online platforms that allow rapid, wide dissemination of urban legend stories.
Various online and offline communication channels and media used to share stories and information, such as websites, apps, and broadcast media.

cluster_classes.class_description: Cultural processes by which stories are communicated, passed between generations, and gradually adapted over time, including oral storytelling and intergenerational transmission.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: shared orally, passed down from one generation to the next, and evolved over time

members.entity_description: The practice of sharing tales verbally and passing them between generations.
Passing stories from one generation to the next within a culture.
The gradual change and adaptation of stories over time.

cluster_classes.class_description: Distinct cultural groups and identities whose shared interests and anxieties shape the formation and evolution of tales and urban legends.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Tales evolved over time to suit the interests and fears of different cultures and their distinct cultural groups.

members.entity_description: Distinct cultural groups whose shared interests and fears shape urban legends.

cluster_classes.class_description: Groups of people (large or small) in which urban legends are shared, transmitted, and maintained, often for mutual protection and social cohesion.
cluster_classes.class_group: Urban Legend Social Actors and Groups
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: urban legends take on a life of their own as they are shared and retold in communities… By sharing these tales, communities can come together

members.entity_description: Groups of people, in both large and small settings, among whom urban legends are shared.
Groups of people sharing and transmitting urban legends to promote mutual protection.

remarks: This class contains two entities both labeled 'communities' with near-identical descriptions; this likely reflects duplicate or overly granular entity entries and should be reviewed for possible upstream entity deduplication.

cluster_classes.class_description: The Hook Man urban legend as an overall narrative concept, covering the core story pattern and its common variations across tellings.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: All three refer to the same underlying urban legend (the Hook Man story)... While the specifics of the story may vary...

members.entity_description: A famous modern urban legend about a murderous figure with a hook for a hand, told in many narrative versions worldwide.

members.entity_name: story specifics of the Hook Man legend
members.entity_description: The variable narrative details and plot elements within different versions of the Hook Man urban legend.

cluster_classes.class_description: Social and economic mechanisms—such as trade, travel, and interconnected societies—that link regions and enable the cross-cultural spread of stories, ideas, and legends.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: As societies became more interconnected through trade and travel, urban legends began to spread across regions and continents.

members.entity_description: Societies linked through trade and travel, facilitating the spread of legends.
Exchange of goods and services that contributes to cross-cultural contact.
Movement of people between places that helps spread stories and legends.

cluster_classes.class_description: Real-world persons, events, or other concrete references that are used as source material or anchors within urban legend narratives.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Stories may be based on real events or historical figures; many are the product of collective imagination and creativity.

members.entity_description: Notable people from history who may be referenced in certain stories.

cluster_classes.class_description: Macro-level social and cultural environments that shape the circulation and reception of phenomena such as urban legends in the present era.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Mainstream cultural environment and contemporary social context where urban legends circulate.

members.entity_description: The mainstream cultural environment where widely shared stories, media, and phenomena such as urban legends circulate and influence discourse.
Contemporary social context in which urban legends are prevalent.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concepts related to narrative explanations of unknown or supernatural phenomena across history, including the stories themselves and the broad historical periods in which they arose.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Origins of urban legends in ancient times when stories explained the unknown and supernatural.

cluster_classes.class_description: Collective fears and anxieties held by societies and cultural groups that are reflected in narratives such as tales and urban legends.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: urban legends ... reflect the fears and anxieties of society

members.entity_description: Collective worries and concerns held by a society that are reflected or mirrored in urban legends.
Human communities whose shared fears, anxieties, and imagination shape urban legends.
Culturally specific anxieties that influence the content of tales and legends.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concepts concerned with the scholarly and analytical study of urban legends as a narrative and cultural phenomenon, including their origins, authenticity, variations, and social impact.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: origins, authenticity, and variations of urban legends as a narrative tradition

members.entity_description: Different versions, adaptations, or altered forms of a core urban legend story that emerge over time or across regions.
The sources, beginnings, and historical development of urban legends, including how specific legends first arose and evolved as a narrative tradition.
The degree to which urban legends are genuine or fact-based.

members.entity_name: impact of urban legends on society
members.entity_description: Influence that urban legends exert on social attitudes, behaviors, and cultural norms.

cluster_classes.class_description: The specific written essay that explores the origins, impact, and endurance of urban legends, treated as a document-level information artifact.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: “In this essay, we will explore the origins of urban legends, their impact on society…”

members.entity_description: The specific written work that will explore origins, impact, and endurance of urban legends.

remarks: This class now intentionally represents the concrete essay/document only; analytic concepts previously mixed into this class have been moved to the analytic class.

cluster_classes.class_description: Family members or close associates that communities aim to protect by sharing urban legends and related cautionary stories.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: communities can come together to protect themselves and their loved ones from perceived threats

members.entity_description: Family members or close associates that communities aim to protect by sharing legends.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concepts and distinctions between objective reality and invented story content, including facts, fiction, real events, and the blurred boundary between them within narratives.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The line between fact and fiction is often blurred... ponder the truth behind the stories

members.entity_description: The conceptual boundary distinguishing objective truth from invented or embellished narrative, often blurred in storytelling.
Information or events considered objectively true and verifiable.
Actual reality or factual basis underlying the stories being told.
Actual historical or factual occurrences that may underlie some stories.
Invented or imagined content within stories, contrasting with factual material.

cluster_classes.class_description: Individuals and groups who receive, listen to, or engage with stories and urban legends, from specific listeners to the global audience.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: People who hear and reflect on urban legends; groups of listeners or readers captivated by urban legends.

members.entity_description: People who hear and reflect on urban legends and other stories.
Groups of listeners or readers who engage with and are captivated by urban legends.
Global population whose imagination and curiosity are captured by urban legends.
Worldwide collection of people who can receive urban legends via internet and social media.

cluster_classes.class_description: Narrative content, including stories and urban legends, that is disseminated through various channels to different audiences.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: stories can be shared and disseminated at lightning speed, reaching a global audience ... around the world

members.entity_description: Narratives, including urban legends, that can be quickly shared online to many people.

cluster_classes.class_label: Bait Objects in Child-Luring Urban Legends
cluster_classes.class_description: Tempting objects (such as candy) used by predators as bait to lure children in cautionary urban legend narratives.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Stories of strangers luring children with candy ... warn listeners about the dangers

members.entity_description: Sweets used as bait by strangers in cautionary tales about child luring.

cluster_classes.class_description: Listeners and audiences who receive the implied warnings and moral lessons from cautionary urban legend stories.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Stories of strangers luring children with candy ... warn listeners about the dangers

members.entity_description: People who hear these urban legends and receive the implied warnings about danger.

cluster_classes.class_label: Psychological and Cultural Constructs of Urban Legends
cluster_classes.class_description: Abstract psychological and cultural constructs—both individual and collective—that are engaged, shaped, or expressed through the creation, adaptation, and reception of urban legends.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Urban legends capture the imagination and curiosity of people and are products of collective imagination.

members.entity_description: Mental capacity engaged and stimulated by hearing and sharing urban legends.
Desire to know and learn more that is triggered by urban legends.
Shared mental creativity of a group that generates stories and myths.
Cultural preferences that shape how stories are adapted and retold.
Shared mental and cultural space where societies generate, store, and transform urban legends.
The capacity of urban legends to amuse, thrill, or engage audiences as a form of entertainment.
Human capacity to invent and elaborate imaginative stories like urban legends.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concrete narrative elements that compose specific tellings of the Hook Man urban legend, including characters (young couple, escaped criminal), setting (secluded area), props (car door, hook), and key events (scratching sound, discovery of the bloody hook).
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: the couple becomes increasingly terrified as they hear a scratching sound on the car door, only to discover a bloody hook hanging from the handle

members.entity_description: An ominous scratching noise heard by the couple on the car door in the story.
The door of the couple’s car where the scratching sound is heard.
A blood-covered hook found hanging from the car door handle in the Hook Man story.
The handle of the car door from which the bloody hook is discovered hanging.
An isolated location where the young couple parks in the Hook Man story.
A broadcast news message warning about an escaped criminal that the couple hears.
A fugitive offender described in the news report who has a hook for a hand in the Hook Man legend.
A pair of young people featured as protagonists in the Hook Man urban legend scenario.
A metal hook replacing the hand of the escaped criminal in the Hook Man legend.

cluster_classes.class_label: Child Victims in Cautionary Urban Legends
cluster_classes.class_description: Children portrayed as vulnerable targets or victims in cautionary urban legend narratives, particularly in child-luring scenarios.

members.entity_description: Young people portrayed as vulnerable targets of predatory strangers in cautionary urban legends.

cluster_classes.class_description: Stories and tales, particularly urban legends, used historically to explain unknown and supernatural phenomena and reflect societal fears and anxieties.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Origins of urban legends in ancient times when stories explained the unknown and supernatural.

members.entity_description: Narrative stories and tales, particularly urban legends, used historically to explain unknown and supernatural phenomena and reflecting societal fears and anxieties.

cluster_classes.class_description: Historical periods (such as ancient times) that serve as the temporal context for early explanatory stories about the unknown and supernatural.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Origins of urban legends in ancient times when stories explained the unknown and supernatural.

members.entity_description: A distant historical period when early explanatory stories about the unknown were told.

cluster_classes.class_description: Geographic units and spatial scope terms describing how widely narratives or legends are disseminated (e.g., regions, continents, worldwide).
cluster_classes.class_group: Spatial Reach & Geography of Story Dissemination
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: urban legends began to spread across regions and continents

members.entity_description: Geographical areas across which urban legends spread.
Large landmasses mentioned as destinations for spreading urban legends.
Global scope of dissemination of the Hook Man story.

cluster_classes.class_description: The contemporary body of traditional stories, beliefs, and narrative practices—including but not limited to urban legends—that circulate within modern societies. This class consolidates the legacy composite handling of modern folklore and its urban-legend subdomain into a single, stable category.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: modern folklore explicitly includes urban legends as part of contemporary traditional stories and beliefs

members.entity_description: The contemporary body of traditional stories, beliefs, and tales, including urban legends, that circulate within modern societies.

cluster_classes.class_label: Urban Legend Emotional Themes and Responses
cluster_classes.class_description: Emotional and psychological states and themes associated with urban legends, including underlying fears (e.g., fear of the unknown, perceived threats) and the felt responses they elicit (e.g., a good scare, motivating fears).
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: the underlying fear of the unknown and the threat of danger remain constant in urban legends

members.entity_description: A core emotional theme driving the tension in the Hook Man urban legend.
A perceived risk or menace that persists across versions of the Hook Man legend.
Threats that people believe exist, whether they are real or imagined, referenced in legends.
The emotional experience of being pleasantly frightened by stories or legends.
Personal or collective fears that motivate engagement with and creation of urban legends.

cluster_classes.class_description: Urban legends as a form of modern folklore: contemporary narrative stories that blend fact and fiction, reflect social fears and anxieties, and their dissemination and proliferation through communities and media.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Urban legends as modern folklore and their spread and proliferation across regions and media.

members.entity_description: A category of modern folklore stories, such as the Hook Man, that circulate widely within communities through oral and digital transmission.
Dissemination of urban legends across regions and continents.
The widespread increase and spread of urban legends in society and media.

Narrative stories within modern folklore, often fictional, that spread socially through communities and communication technologies, blending fact and fiction and frequently reflecting societal fears and anxieties.

args.new_name: Narrative Explanations of the Unknown and Their Historical Origins
args.new_description: Stories and tales, particularly early urban-legend-like narratives, used to explain unknown and supernatural phenomena across history, including both the narratives themselves and the historical periods in which they arose.
args.justification: ClsC_351d72f0 (Historical Narrative Concepts) is empty and conceptually overlaps with ClsR_de142256 (Narrative Explanations of the Unknown) around stories explaining the unknown and supernatural across history, so they should be consolidated into a single, clearer class under the same class_group.

args.new_name: Story and Legend Audiences (including Cautionary Narratives)
args.new_description: Individuals and groups who receive, listen to, or engage with stories and urban legends, including general audiences and those specifically receiving warnings and moral lessons from cautionary urban legend stories.
args.justification: Both classes model essentially the same audience role ('listeners' and broader audiences of stories and legends), with ClsR_19f6228d being a narrow, single-entity subtype; merging removes redundant duplication and yields one coherent audience class for narratives, preserving the existing class_group for narrative dissemination.

After merging the two audience classes into a single narrative-audience class, the unified class should retain and standardize on the existing, appropriate class_group label used for storytelling and narrative dissemination roles.

The merged class inherits both predecessors' focus on historical narrative explanations of the unknown and should remain in the existing higher-level group that connects narrative truth, fiction, and historical origins.

ClsR_0dcfbe42 currently uses a slightly different class_group label ('Urban Legends & Modern Folklore') than related classes ClsR_1804969e and ClsC_bbd396a2 ('Urban Legends and Modern Folklore'); standardizing the class_group string improves schema coherence for the core modern-folklore domain.

executed_decisions.justification: ClsC_351d72f0 (Historical Narrative Concepts) is empty and conceptually overlaps with ClsR_de142256 (Narrative Explanations of the Unknown) around stories explaining the unknown and supernatural across history, so they should be consolidated into a single, clearer class under the same class_group.

Both classes model essentially the same audience role ('listeners' and broader audiences of stories and legends), with ClsR_19f6228d being a narrow, single-entity subtype; merging removes redundant duplication and yields one coherent audience class for narratives, preserving the existing class_group for narrative dissemination.

After merging the two audience classes into a single narrative-audience class, the unified class should retain and standardize on the existing, appropriate class_group label used for storytelling and narrative dissemination roles.

The merged class inherits both predecessors' focus on historical narrative explanations of the unknown and should remain in the existing higher-level group that connects narrative truth, fiction, and historical origins.

ClsR_0dcfbe42 currently uses a slightly different class_group label ('Urban Legends & Modern Folklore') than related classes ClsR_1804969e and ClsC_bbd396a2 ('Urban Legends and Modern Folklore'); standardizing the class_group string improves schema coherence for the core modern-folklore domain.

cluster_classes.class_description: Deprecated high-level aggregate for flowering plant reproduction. This class was previously used to bundle organisms (flowering plants), reproductive processes (pollination), and structures, but has been superseded by more specific classes: Plant Reproductive Structures, Pollination (Flowering Plant Process), and Flowering Plants (Organisms). It is retained only for backward compatibility and should not receive new members.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Pollination transfers pollen between flowers, enabling plant reproduction; plants are the organisms whose reproduction is assisted.
remarks: This class has been structurally split into separate process (pollination) and organism (flowering plants) classes and may now have no direct members; consider deprecating or repurposing in a later cleanup pass.

This class has no members and its original scope is now cleanly covered by ClsC_fb0a1cd7 (Plant Reproductive Structures), ClsR_9ddc1c4b (Pollination (Flowering Plant Process)), and ClsR_2f847eb5 (Flowering Plants (Organisms)). Treat this as a deprecated aggregate container; avoid assigning new entities here and migrate any legacy members into the more specific classes.

This class is an empty, deprecated aggregate whose semantic scope is fully covered by more specific classes; moving it into a dedicated 'Deprecated & Legacy Container Classes' group prevents it from being treated as an active semantic node in the flowering plant/pollination domain.

cluster_classes.class_label: Deprecated: Urban Legend Elements (superseded by split classes)
cluster_classes.class_description: Legacy container class that previously mixed bait objects and audience roles for cautionary urban legends; its members have been moved into more specific split classes.
cluster_classes.class_group: Cautionary Urban Legends – Child Luring Scenarios
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Stories of strangers luring children with candy ... warn listeners about the dangers
remarks: This class is now empty after splitting its members into more specific classes and can be treated as deprecated or removed in a future cleanup step.
This class is fully empty after prior splits and should be treated as deprecated; avoid assigning new entities and consider archiving or deleting it in a dedicated cleanup step.

This class is an empty legacy container that has been fully superseded by split classes; moving it into a dedicated 'Deprecated & Legacy Container Classes' group avoids falsely connecting it to active urban-legend schema while keeping it available for legacy compatibility.

args.remark: This class is an empty, deprecated aggregate whose semantic scope is fully covered by more specific classes; moving it into a dedicated 'Deprecated & Legacy Container Classes' group prevents it from being treated as an active semantic node in the flowering plant/pollination domain.
args.justification: As a fully deprecated, empty aggregate that only exists for backward compatibility, this class should not remain in an active domain-specific group; assigning it to a dedicated deprecated/legacy class_group keeps the semantic graph clean while preserving the class for legacy references.

args.remark: This class is an empty legacy container that has been fully superseded by split classes; moving it into a dedicated 'Deprecated & Legacy Container Classes' group avoids falsely connecting it to active urban-legend schema while keeping it available for legacy compatibility.
args.justification: Because this class is empty and explicitly deprecated in favor of more specific split classes, it should be grouped with other deprecated containers rather than with active urban-legend semantics, preventing confusion in the high-level schema.

executed_decisions.remark: This class is an empty, deprecated aggregate whose semantic scope is fully covered by more specific classes; moving it into a dedicated 'Deprecated & Legacy Container Classes' group prevents it from being treated as an active semantic node in the flowering plant/pollination domain.
executed_decisions.justification: As a fully deprecated, empty aggregate that only exists for backward compatibility, this class should not remain in an active domain-specific group; assigning it to a dedicated deprecated/legacy class_group keeps the semantic graph clean while preserving the class for legacy references.

executed_decisions.remark: This class is an empty legacy container that has been fully superseded by split classes; moving it into a dedicated 'Deprecated & Legacy Container Classes' group avoids falsely connecting it to active urban-legend schema while keeping it available for legacy compatibility.
executed_decisions.justification: Because this class is empty and explicitly deprecated in favor of more specific split classes, it should be grouped with other deprecated containers rather than with active urban-legend semantics, preventing confusion in the high-level schema.

cluster_classes.class_description: Components of flowering plants directly involved in sexual reproduction and pollination, including whole flowers and the pollen grains they produce and exchange.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Reproductive structures of plants that provide nectar and pollen… specific reproductive material moved by butterflies among flowers.

members.entity_description: Reproductive structures of plants that provide nectar and pollen and are visited by butterflies.
Reproductive plant grains that butterflies transfer between flowers during pollination.

cluster_classes.class_description: The biological process in which pollen is transferred between flowers, enabling sexual reproduction in flowering plants, often facilitated by animals such as butterflies.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Pollination transfers pollen between flowers, enabling plant reproduction; plants are the organisms whose reproduction is assisted.

members.entity_description: Biological process in which pollen is transferred between flowers, enabling plant reproduction, often facilitated by animals such as butterflies.

cluster_classes.class_description: Organisms that reproduce via flowers and benefit from pollination, including those whose reproduction is assisted by butterflies.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Pollination transfers pollen between flowers, enabling plant reproduction; plants are the organisms whose reproduction is assisted.

members.entity_description: Organisms that reproduce via flowers and benefit from pollination by butterflies.

splits.name: Flowers (Plant Reproductive Structures)
splits.description: Flowers as the reproductive structures of plants that provide nectar and pollen and are visited by pollinators such as butterflies.

splits.name: Pollen (Plant Reproductive Material)
splits.description: Pollen grains as the reproductive material of plants that are transferred between flowers during pollination.

args.justification: The original class mixes a structural entity (flowers) and a particulate reproductive material (pollen) with different entity_type_hints, so splitting improves semantic coherence between structures and materials.

args.new_description: Flowers as the reproductive structures of plants that provide nectar and pollen and are visited by pollinators such as butterflies.
args.new_class_group: Flowering Plant Reproduction (Plants, Structures, Materials & Processes)
args.justification: Assign a precise name, type, and shared Class_Group reflecting that flowers are distinct plant structures within the broader flowering plant reproduction context.

args.new_description: Pollen grains as the reproductive material of plants that are transferred between flowers during pollination, often by pollinators such as butterflies.
args.new_class_group: Flowering Plant Reproduction (Plants, Structures, Materials & Processes)
args.justification: Clarify that this class is for pollen as a reproductive material, not a structure, and align it with the same overarching flowering plant reproduction Class_Group.

args.new_class_group: Flowering Plant Reproduction (Plants, Structures, Materials & Processes)
args.justification: Update the Class_Group label to a more explicit shared grouping that connects plants, structures, materials, and the pollination process under flowering plant reproduction.

args.new_class_group: Flowering Plant Reproduction (Plants, Structures, Materials & Processes)
args.justification: Align this organism-focused class with the same refined Class_Group used for flowers, pollen, and pollination to clearly model all components of flowering plant reproduction together.

executed_decisions.justification: The original class mixes a structural entity (flowers) and a particulate reproductive material (pollen) with different entity_type_hints, so splitting improves semantic coherence between structures and materials.

executed_decisions.new_description: Flowers as the reproductive structures of plants that provide nectar and pollen and are visited by pollinators such as butterflies.
executed_decisions.new_class_group: Flowering Plant Reproduction (Plants, Structures, Materials & Processes)
executed_decisions.justification: Assign a precise name, type, and shared Class_Group reflecting that flowers are distinct plant structures within the broader flowering plant reproduction context.

executed_decisions.new_description: Pollen grains as the reproductive material of plants that are transferred between flowers during pollination, often by pollinators such as butterflies.
executed_decisions.new_class_group: Flowering Plant Reproduction (Plants, Structures, Materials & Processes)
executed_decisions.justification: Clarify that this class is for pollen as a reproductive material, not a structure, and align it with the same overarching flowering plant reproduction Class_Group.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Flowering Plant Reproduction (Plants, Structures, Materials & Processes)
executed_decisions.justification: Update the Class_Group label to a more explicit shared grouping that connects plants, structures, materials, and the pollination process under flowering plant reproduction.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Flowering Plant Reproduction (Plants, Structures, Materials & Processes)
executed_decisions.justification: Align this organism-focused class with the same refined Class_Group used for flowers, pollen, and pollination to clearly model all components of flowering plant reproduction together.

cluster_classes.class_description: Broad, system-level ecological constructs that describe whole environments and their overarching structure, such as ecosystems and the natural world context in which organisms exist.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: ecological community and its environment … wider ecological context of butterfly existence

members.entity_description: The integrated ecological community of organisms and their physical environment where caterpillars and butterflies interact as pollinators, prey, and participants in ecological processes.
The broad ecological and biological systems, including all living organisms and their environments, of which butterfly life cycles are a part.

cluster_classes.class_description: Ecological conditions or metrics that characterize the status of biological communities, including biodiversity levels and the balance of plant populations.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: state where plant species abundances are maintained … richness and variety of organisms

members.entity_description: Ecological state where plant species abundances are maintained, influenced by caterpillars.
The variety and variability of living organisms and ecological complexes within an ecosystem to which butterflies contribute.

cluster_classes.class_description: Ecological processes, connections, and biotic interactions within ecosystems, excluding specific organism roles like predators which are modeled separately.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Predators and the complex web of ecological and biological interactions and processes within ecosystems.

members.entity_description: The complex web of ecological and biological interactions and processes within ecosystems, highlighted through studying butterfly life cycles.

cluster_classes.class_description: Organisms that act as predators within ecosystems, influencing prey species such as caterpillars and shaping ecological dynamics.

members.entity_description: Animals that prey on caterpillars, driving their protective adaptations.

cluster_classes.class_label: Butterfly Predators, Prey Role, and Predation Risk
cluster_classes.class_description: Predators of butterflies and their eggs/larvae (birds, reptiles, other insects, and unspecified predators), the ecological role of butterflies as prey within food webs, and behaviors/locations such as egg-laying on leaf undersides that reduce predation risk.
cluster_classes.class_group: Butterfly Ecology: Host Plants, Predators & Anti-predator Strategies
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Eggs laid on the underside of leaves to protect them from predators.

members.entity_description: The lower surface of plant leaves where butterfly eggs are commonly laid.
Animals that might eat or harm butterfly eggs on leaves.
The ecological role of butterflies as prey for birds, reptiles, and other insects.
Vertebrate animals that consume butterflies as part of their diet.
Cold-blooded vertebrates identified as predators that eat butterflies.
Insect species besides butterflies that prey on butterflies as food.

args.justification: Entities in ClsR_5aa32109 describing concrete predator organisms (generic predators, birds, reptiles, other insects) match the scope of ClsR_04475627 (predator organisms) better than the mixed interaction/behavior scope of ClsR_5aa32109, so they should be consolidated under the dedicated predator-organism class.

args.new_description: Organisms that act as predators of caterpillars, butterfly eggs, larvae, and adults within ecosystems, influencing prey species and shaping ecological dynamics.
args.justification: After moving all predator-organism entities into ClsR_04475627, renaming and slightly broadening the description clarifies that this class covers all predators of caterpillars and butterflies and remains aligned with the existing Ecology and Ecosystems group.

args.new_name: Butterfly Prey Role and Anti-predator Strategies
args.new_description: The ecological role of butterflies as prey within food webs and the behaviors or spatial strategies, such as laying eggs on the underside of leaves, that reduce predation risk.
args.justification: Once predator-organism entities are reassigned, ClsR_5aa32109 is focused on butterflies' role as prey and their anti-predator strategies; renaming and simplifying the description to exclude explicit predator taxa and aligning its class_group with the other ecological interaction classes creates a cleaner, more coherent schema.

executed_decisions.justification: Entities in ClsR_5aa32109 describing concrete predator organisms (generic predators, birds, reptiles, other insects) match the scope of ClsR_04475627 (predator organisms) better than the mixed interaction/behavior scope of ClsR_5aa32109, so they should be consolidated under the dedicated predator-organism class.

executed_decisions.new_description: Organisms that act as predators of caterpillars, butterfly eggs, larvae, and adults within ecosystems, influencing prey species and shaping ecological dynamics.
executed_decisions.justification: After moving all predator-organism entities into ClsR_04475627, renaming and slightly broadening the description clarifies that this class covers all predators of caterpillars and butterflies and remains aligned with the existing Ecology and Ecosystems group.

executed_decisions.new_name: Butterfly Prey Role and Anti-predator Strategies
executed_decisions.new_description: The ecological role of butterflies as prey within food webs and the behaviors or spatial strategies, such as laying eggs on the underside of leaves, that reduce predation risk.
executed_decisions.justification: Once predator-organism entities are reassigned, ClsR_5aa32109 is focused on butterflies' role as prey and their anti-predator strategies; renaming and simplifying the description to exclude explicit predator taxa and aligning its class_group with the other ecological interaction classes creates a cleaner, more coherent schema.

cluster_classes.class_description: Defensive behavioral adaptations in which caterpillars visually blend into their environment, including general background matching and specific mimicry of plant parts such as twigs and leaves.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Some caterpillars ... mimic the appearance of twigs or leaves to camouflage themselves from predators.

members.entity_description: Defensive strategy where caterpillars visually blend into surroundings to avoid predators.
Caterpillar camouflage strategy where individuals resemble twigs.
Caterpillar camouflage strategy in which individuals resemble leaves.

cluster_classes.class_description: Anatomical defensive structures on caterpillars, such as spines and hairs, that provide physical protection against predators and other threats.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Some caterpillars have spines or hairs for protection... protective adaptations.

members.entity_description: Defensive protrusions on some caterpillars used as protection against threats.
Hair-like structures on some caterpillars providing physical protection.
Combined defensive structures on caterpillars used to protect them from threats.

cluster_classes.class_label: Butterfly Host Plants and Oviposition Sites
cluster_classes.class_description: Host plants and their structures (e.g., leaves, undersides of leaves) that serve as oviposition sites and food sources for butterfly eggs, larvae, and chrysalides.
cluster_classes.class_group: Butterfly Ecology: Host Plants, Predators & Anti-predator Strategies
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Plants and their leaves used for egg-laying and larval feeding in the butterfly life cycle.

members.entity_description: Plant leaves that serve as sites for egg-laying, feeding by caterpillars, and attachment for chrysalis formation.
Specific plants on which female butterflies deposit their eggs and that serve as food sources and habitat for early butterfly life stages.
The lower surface of plant leaves where butterfly eggs are commonly laid.

cluster_classes.class_description: Behaviors of caterpillars specifically related to consuming plant leaves as a primary food source.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Caterpillars feeding on plant leaves as their main activity and food source.

members.entity_description: Primary caterpillar activity of consuming plant leaves for nutrition.

cluster_classes.class_label: Plant Structures as Caterpillar Environmental Context
cluster_classes.class_description: Physical plant parts (e.g., leaves, stems, twigs) that serve as environmental structures, visual backgrounds, or attachment points in caterpillar life stages (including camouflage and chrysalis formation).
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Leaves, stems, and twigs are plant parts used as background or attachment points.

members.entity_description: Plant leaves that are visually imitated by certain caterpillars for concealment.
Small plant branches whose appearance is mimicked by some caterpillars.

cluster_classes.class_description: Plant structures (such as leaves and stems) used by caterpillars and butterflies as physical substrates for egg-laying, feeding, and chrysalis attachment.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Caterpillars feeding on plant leaves as their main activity and food source.

members.entity_description: Plant leaves that serve as sites for egg-laying, feeding by caterpillars, and attachment for chrysalis formation.
Plant stem that serves as an attachment point for the caterpillar before forming a chrysalis.

args.new_name: Plant Structures as Lepidopteran Substrate and Background
args.new_description: Plant structures (e.g., host plants, leaves, undersides of leaves, stems, twigs) used by butterflies and caterpillars as oviposition sites, feeding and chrysalis substrates, and visual backgrounds for camouflage across life stages.
args.justification: These three classes all describe the same conceptual domain—plant structures (leaves, stems, twigs, host plants) serving as substrates or environmental context for butterfly/caterpillar eggs, larvae, and chrysalides—with duplicated entities (e.g., 'plant leaves') and overlapping roles (egg-laying, feeding, chrysalis attachment, camouflage), so they should be combined into a single coherent class.
args.remark: Merged former classes: 'Butterfly Host Plants and Oviposition Sites', 'Plant Structures as Caterpillar Environmental Context', and 'Plant Structures as Caterpillar Substrate' due to near-identical scope over plant parts used as substrates/backgrounds for lepidopteran life stages.

args.justification: The merged plant-structure class covers both butterflies and caterpillars and represents how they use plant parts as habitat and interaction surfaces, so a unified Class_Group 'Lepidopteran Plant Interactions & Habitat' better connects it conceptually to related plant-use behaviors.

Caterpillar leaf-feeding behavior is a direct plant interaction and belongs in the same higher-level domain as plant substrates and host plants; aligning its Class_Group with the merged plant-structure class strengthens the shared schema for lepidopteran–plant interactions.

executed_decisions.justification: These three classes all describe the same conceptual domain—plant structures (leaves, stems, twigs, host plants) serving as substrates or environmental context for butterfly/caterpillar eggs, larvae, and chrysalides—with duplicated entities (e.g., 'plant leaves') and overlapping roles (egg-laying, feeding, chrysalis attachment, camouflage), so they should be combined into a single coherent class.
executed_decisions.remark: Merged former classes: 'Butterfly Host Plants and Oviposition Sites', 'Plant Structures as Caterpillar Environmental Context', and 'Plant Structures as Caterpillar Substrate' due to near-identical scope over plant parts used as substrates/backgrounds for lepidopteran life stages.

executed_decisions.justification: The merged plant-structure class covers both butterflies and caterpillars and represents how they use plant parts as habitat and interaction surfaces, so a unified Class_Group 'Lepidopteran Plant Interactions & Habitat' better connects it conceptually to related plant-use behaviors.

Caterpillar leaf-feeding behavior is a direct plant interaction and belongs in the same higher-level domain as plant substrates and host plants; aligning its Class_Group with the merged plant-structure class strengthens the shared schema for lepidopteran–plant interactions.

cluster_classes.class_description: Distinct developmental stages in the butterfly life cycle, from egg to larval caterpillar, treated as organismal life stages rather than specific anatomical parts.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: egg life stage and larval life stage (caterpillar) within the butterfly life cycle

members.entity_description: The initial life stage of a butterfly during which the organism exists as eggs laid on host plants before hatching into larvae (caterpillars), with eggs varying in size, shape, and color by species.
The larval life stage of butterflies, beginning when the egg hatches into a caterpillar and encompassing the primary feeding, rapid growth, and preparation for pupation.

cluster_classes.class_description: The adult (imago) stage of butterflies, including the general adult form, its immediate post-emergence period, and attributes such as typical lifespan and activity during this stage.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: newly emerged adult butterfly… moment of beauty and grace in flight

members.entity_description: An adult butterfly immediately after leaving the chrysalis, before its wings have fully expanded and hardened.

The fourth and final life stage of butterflies, when they are winged, sexually mature insects that feed (often on nectar), pollinate, and focus on mating and reproduction, typically living from a few days to a few weeks depending on species.
The duration of the adult stage of a butterfly's life, typically from a few days to a few weeks depending on species.
The fourth and final life cycle stage of a butterfly, when the fully developed adult butterfly emerges from the chrysalis, flies, feeds, mates, and reproduces.

args.name: Butterfly Adult Stage Attributes
args.description: Attributes and characteristics specific to the adult (imago) stage of butterflies, such as typical duration of the adult stage and related life-history parameters.
args.justification: The entity 'butterfly adult lifespan' is an attribute of the adult stage rather than the life stage itself, so it should be moved into its own attribute-focused class.
Move 'butterfly adult lifespan' out of the Adult Butterfly Life Stage class into a new attribute-focused class, separating stages from their quantitative/descriptive attributes.
Assign the new attribute-focused class to the same overarching butterfly life cycle domain as the life stage classes.

args.new_name: Early Butterfly Life Stages (Egg and Larva)
args.new_description: The early developmental stages in the butterfly life cycle, specifically the egg and larval (caterpillar) stages, treated as organismal life stages rather than anatomical parts.
args.justification: Clarify that this class covers only the egg and larval stages, distinguishing it more clearly from the adult stage class while keeping it in the same life cycle group.

args.new_description: The adult (imago) stage of butterflies, including newly emerged adults and fully mature winged individuals that are capable of flight, feeding, and reproduction.
args.justification: Refine the description to focus solely on the adult stage itself, now that lifespan has been moved to an attribute class, and ensure consistent life-stage typing within the same life cycle group.

executed_decisions.justification: The entity 'butterfly adult lifespan' is an attribute of the adult stage rather than the life stage itself, so it should be moved into its own attribute-focused class.
Move 'butterfly adult lifespan' out of the Adult Butterfly Life Stage class into a new attribute-focused class, separating stages from their quantitative/descriptive attributes.
Assign the new attribute-focused class to the same overarching butterfly life cycle domain as the life stage classes.

executed_decisions.new_name: Early Butterfly Life Stages (Egg and Larva)
executed_decisions.new_description: The early developmental stages in the butterfly life cycle, specifically the egg and larval (caterpillar) stages, treated as organismal life stages rather than anatomical parts.
executed_decisions.justification: Clarify that this class covers only the egg and larval stages, distinguishing it more clearly from the adult stage class while keeping it in the same life cycle group.

executed_decisions.new_description: The adult (imago) stage of butterflies, including newly emerged adults and fully mature winged individuals that are capable of flight, feeding, and reproduction.
executed_decisions.justification: Refine the description to focus solely on the adult stage itself, now that lifespan has been moved to an attribute class, and ensure consistent life-stage typing within the same life cycle group.

cluster_classes.class_description: Developmental stages of a butterfly from egg through larval and pupal stages to the adult form, including references to specific later stages such as the pupa (chrysalis) and adult phases.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: All entities describe the butterfly life cycle or specific life stages (pupa/chrysalis, adult).

members.entity_description: The full developmental sequence or journey of a butterfly from egg through larval and pupal stages to the adult form, recurring across generations.

members.entity_name: pupa stage of the butterfly life cycle
members.entity_description: The third developmental stage of a butterfly, in which the organism becomes a pupa enclosed in a chrysalis and undergoes metamorphosis from larva to adult.

cluster_classes.class_description: Processes in adult butterflies related to securing mates and producing offspring, including mating behavior and the act of reproduction itself, which occur during the adult stage of the life cycle.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Throughout their adult stage, butterflies focus on finding a mate and reproducing to continue the life cycle.

members.entity_description: The activity of butterflies seeking and finding mates during the adult stage.
The process by which adult butterflies produce offspring, continuing the life cycle.

cluster_classes.class_description: Anatomical wing structures of butterflies, including their initial post-emergence physical states prior to functional flight.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: wings of a butterfly… initial post-emergence state of a butterfly’s wings

members.entity_description: The flight-enabling appendages of a butterfly that develop during metamorphosis and must expand and harden before enabling flight.
The initial post-emergence state of a butterfly’s wings, when they are soft and wrinkled before expansion and hardening.

cluster_classes.class_description: Physiological and behavioral processes as a butterfly transitions from chrysalis to functional adult, including wing expansion and first flight.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: pumping fluid into wings to expand and harden… ready to take flight for the first time

members.entity_description: Process by which a butterfly circulates fluid into its wings to expand and harden them.
The initial act of flying that a butterfly performs after its wings develop.

cluster_classes.class_description: Biological and developmental processes involved in a caterpillar's transformation within the chrysalis into an adult butterfly, including metamorphosis and broader morphological changes, excluding the adult organism itself.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Transformation of a caterpillar inside the chrysalis into an adult butterfly, described as astonishing transformations.

members.entity_description: Transformation process in which a caterpillar's body reorganizes inside the chrysalis and develops into an adult butterfly.
Remarkable morphological and developmental changes occurring across butterfly life stages.

cluster_classes.class_description: Biological and anatomical structures and materials involved in butterfly metamorphosis, including larval body structures, dissolved organs and liquefied material, the chrysalis, and newly forming tissues and appendages such as wings and antennae.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Organs dissolve into a soupy substance, and new tissues and structures, such as wings and antennae, begin to form.

members.entity_description: Internal biological structures of the caterpillar that dissolve during metamorphosis.
Liquid-like biological material formed when caterpillar organs dissolve inside the chrysalis during metamorphosis.
Fresh biological tissues that develop from liquefied organs during metamorphosis.
Sensory appendages that develop as new structures during butterfly metamorphosis.
The hardened, protective casing enclosing the pupa stage of a butterfly, within which metamorphosis occurs and from which the adult butterfly emerges.
The overall physical structure of the caterpillar, including its tissues and organs, that changes significantly during metamorphosis.

cluster_classes.class_description: The perceived aesthetic or experiential state of a butterfly in flight (e.g., beauty, grace), modeled as a phenomenological state rather than a biological life stage.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: newly emerged adult butterfly… moment of beauty and grace in flight

members.entity_description: The perceived aesthetic state of an adult butterfly in flight, characterized as beautiful and graceful.

args.new_class_group: Butterfly Metamorphosis, Anatomy, and Experiential States
args.justification: Unifies this butterfly wing anatomy class into a single, coherent Class_Group with related metamorphosis, anatomical, and experiential classes, replacing the narrower group label 'Butterfly Anatomy and Experiential States'.

args.new_class_group: Butterfly Metamorphosis, Anatomy, and Experiential States
args.justification: Aligns the 'Butterfly Emergence Processes' class with the same overarching Class_Group as other metamorphosis-related processes and structures, instead of the slightly different 'Butterfly Life Cycle & Metamorphosis' label.

args.new_class_group: Butterfly Metamorphosis, Anatomy, and Experiential States
args.justification: Standardizes the Class_Group for this metamorphosis process class to match related emergence processes, anatomical structures, and experiential states, improving schema connectivity.

args.new_class_group: Butterfly Metamorphosis, Anatomy, and Experiential States
args.justification: Updates the Class_Group of the metamorphosis anatomical structures class to a unified label that explicitly covers metamorphosis, anatomy, and related experiential aspects, instead of a partially overlapping group name.

args.new_class_group: Butterfly Metamorphosis, Anatomy, and Experiential States
args.justification: Places the phenomenological 'Butterfly aesthetic state in flight' class in the same overarching Class_Group as the anatomical and process classes involved in metamorphosis and emergence, reflecting their shared domain.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Butterfly Metamorphosis, Anatomy, and Experiential States
executed_decisions.justification: Unifies this butterfly wing anatomy class into a single, coherent Class_Group with related metamorphosis, anatomical, and experiential classes, replacing the narrower group label 'Butterfly Anatomy and Experiential States'.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Butterfly Metamorphosis, Anatomy, and Experiential States
executed_decisions.justification: Aligns the 'Butterfly Emergence Processes' class with the same overarching Class_Group as other metamorphosis-related processes and structures, instead of the slightly different 'Butterfly Life Cycle & Metamorphosis' label.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Butterfly Metamorphosis, Anatomy, and Experiential States
executed_decisions.justification: Standardizes the Class_Group for this metamorphosis process class to match related emergence processes, anatomical structures, and experiential states, improving schema connectivity.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Butterfly Metamorphosis, Anatomy, and Experiential States
executed_decisions.justification: Updates the Class_Group of the metamorphosis anatomical structures class to a unified label that explicitly covers metamorphosis, anatomy, and related experiential aspects, instead of a partially overlapping group name.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Butterfly Metamorphosis, Anatomy, and Experiential States
executed_decisions.justification: Places the phenomenological 'Butterfly aesthetic state in flight' class in the same overarching Class_Group as the anatomical and process classes involved in metamorphosis and emergence, reflecting their shared domain.

cluster_classes.class_description: Former umbrella class for caterpillar growth and molting processes; entities have been moved into more specific subclasses.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Caterpillars grow rapidly and shed their skin several times as they grow.
remarks: This class is now effectively empty after splitting; consider deprecating or hiding it from primary use.
This class is now empty after its contents were split into more specific process classes. Marked as deprecated to prevent future use while preserving backward compatibility.

cluster_classes.class_description: The external anatomical covering of caterpillars, including the skin and associated surface structures that are shed and replaced during growth and molting.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The external anatomical covering of caterpillars that is repeatedly shed and replaced during growth.

members.entity_description: The external anatomical covering of caterpillars that is repeatedly shed and replaced during growth.

cluster_classes.class_description: The rapid increase in size and mass experienced by caterpillars during the larval stage.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Caterpillars grow rapidly and shed their skin several times as they grow.

members.entity_description: The fast increase in size experienced by caterpillars during the larval stage.

cluster_classes.class_description: The periodic shedding and replacement of a caterpillar's external skin (integument) during growth.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Caterpillars grow rapidly and shed their skin several times as they grow.

members.entity_description: Biological process in which caterpillars shed and replace their external skin multiple times as they grow.

args.new_name: DEPRECATED – Caterpillar Growth and Molting (legacy container)
args.new_description: Deprecated umbrella class that formerly grouped caterpillar growth and molting processes. All known entities have been moved into more specific subclasses (e.g., Caterpillar Rapid Growth, Caterpillar Molting Process). This class is retained only for backward compatibility and should not be used for new annotations.
args.remark: This class is now empty after its contents were split into more specific process classes. Marked as deprecated to prevent future use while preserving backward compatibility.
args.justification: The class is effectively empty and explicitly described as a former umbrella; retagging and renaming it as deprecated clarifies its status and prevents misuse while keeping the existing, coherent anatomy and process subclasses intact.

executed_decisions.new_name: DEPRECATED – Caterpillar Growth and Molting (legacy container)
executed_decisions.new_description: Deprecated umbrella class that formerly grouped caterpillar growth and molting processes. All known entities have been moved into more specific subclasses (e.g., Caterpillar Rapid Growth, Caterpillar Molting Process). This class is retained only for backward compatibility and should not be used for new annotations.
executed_decisions.remark: This class is now empty after its contents were split into more specific process classes. Marked as deprecated to prevent future use while preserving backward compatibility.
executed_decisions.justification: The class is effectively empty and explicitly described as a former umbrella; retagging and renaming it as deprecated clarifies its status and prevents misuse while keeping the existing, coherent anatomy and process subclasses intact.

cluster_classes.class_description: How adult butterflies obtain food from flowers, including nectar as a food resource and the proboscis as the specialized feeding structure.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Adult butterflies feed on nectar from flowers using their long, tubular mouthparts called proboscis.

members.entity_description: A sugary liquid in flowers that serves as a food source for adult butterflies.
The long, tubular mouthparts adult butterflies use to feed on nectar.

cluster_classes.class_description: Adult butterflies of the female sex that lay eggs on specific host plants to begin the next generation.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: adult butterflies, including female butterflies that lay eggs on host plants

members.entity_description: Adult butterflies of the female sex that lay eggs on specific host plants to begin the next generation.

args.justification: This class concerns adult butterfly feeding structures and food sources, which is part of the broader domain of butterfly biology and ecology; aligning its class_group with the related female butterfly class supports a coherent upper-level schema.

This class describes female butterflies as organisms within butterfly life history; assigning the same broader class_group as the adult feeding biology class connects related but distinct aspects of butterfly biology.

executed_decisions.justification: This class concerns adult butterfly feeding structures and food sources, which is part of the broader domain of butterfly biology and ecology; aligning its class_group with the related female butterfly class supports a coherent upper-level schema.

This class describes female butterflies as organisms within butterfly life history; assigning the same broader class_group as the adult feeding biology class connects related but distinct aspects of butterfly biology.

cluster_classes.class_description: Intrinsic morphological and visual characteristics of butterfly eggs, including their size, shape, and color, which vary among species.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The size, shape, and color of butterfly eggs vary depending on the species.

members.entity_description: Variation in how large or small butterfly eggs are across species.
Morphological forms of butterfly eggs such as round, cylindrical, or oval.
Observed colors of butterfly eggs, including white, yellow, green, and brown.

cluster_classes.class_description: Taxonomic species of butterflies and their caterpillar (larval) stages, used to explain variation in traits such as shape, color, and lifespan.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Different biological species of caterpillars and distinct taxonomic species of butterflies.

members.entity_description: Different biological species of caterpillars that determine their varied shapes, sizes, and colors.
Distinct taxonomic species of butterflies whose traits, such as lifespan, can vary among them.

args.new_description: Intrinsic morphological and visual characteristics of butterfly eggs, including their size, shape, and color, which vary among species.
args.justification: Broaden the class_group to cover both butterfly and caterpillar life stages (lepidopterans) and slightly refine the name to emphasize morphology while preserving the existing scope.

args.new_description: Taxonomic species of butterflies whose traits (e.g., lifespan, coloration, wing patterns) can vary among them.
args.justification: The entities distinguish butterfly species from caterpillar species; narrowing this class to butterfly taxa and aligning the class_group with Lepidopteran Biology creates a cleaner separation between life-stage-specific taxa.

args.name: Caterpillar species
args.description: Taxonomic species of caterpillars (larval lepidopterans), used to explain variation in larval traits such as body shape, size, and color.
args.justification: One existing entity explicitly describes species of caterpillars distinct from butterfly species; creating a dedicated Caterpillar species class separates larval taxa from adult butterfly taxa.
Entity En_821eccdf refers specifically to species of caterpillars, which semantically belongs in the new Caterpillar species class instead of the now-narrowed Butterfly species class.
Assign the new Caterpillar species class to the same higher-level Lepidopteran Biology group as related butterfly classes, connecting larval and adult taxa under a coherent schema.

executed_decisions.new_description: Intrinsic morphological and visual characteristics of butterfly eggs, including their size, shape, and color, which vary among species.
executed_decisions.justification: Broaden the class_group to cover both butterfly and caterpillar life stages (lepidopterans) and slightly refine the name to emphasize morphology while preserving the existing scope.

executed_decisions.new_description: Taxonomic species of butterflies whose traits (e.g., lifespan, coloration, wing patterns) can vary among them.
executed_decisions.justification: The entities distinguish butterfly species from caterpillar species; narrowing this class to butterfly taxa and aligning the class_group with Lepidopteran Biology creates a cleaner separation between life-stage-specific taxa.
One existing entity explicitly describes species of caterpillars distinct from butterfly species; creating a dedicated Caterpillar species class separates larval taxa from adult butterfly taxa.
Entity En_821eccdf refers specifically to species of caterpillars, which semantically belongs in the new Caterpillar species class instead of the now-narrowed Butterfly species class.
Assign the new Caterpillar species class to the same higher-level Lepidopteran Biology group as related butterfly classes, connecting larval and adult taxa under a coherent schema.
